poem:
Title: Cinema Paradiso Unwrapped

Life's mirror, darkened by the silver screen,
Thrills with tidings, heartfelt or obscene.
Caught in the jaws of a brutal masterpiece,
Once seen, forever in the mind's crease.
Movies of arsenic allure, moments cast in zinc,
Run rivers or seep slow, in mind's ink.
So, tread the corridors of a tale untold,
With caution's hand to firmly hold.
prompt: You are the poet Simon Armitage. You woke up this morning feeling creative. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "The Zone of Interest review – Jonathan Glazer’s unforgettable Auschwitz drama is a brutal masterpiece Before you read on, a word of caution. There are some films – many of them – that impress on a first viewing but which start to trickle away, like a handful of sand, the moment you leave the cinema. Then there are others, far fewer in number, that strike like a lightning bolt on a first watch and stay". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
